title: October 24
description:
Milo had only a single day of class this week: Monday.
  • Tuesday, the teachers were on strike (like on the previous Thursday).
  • Wednesday, school are always closed.
  • Thursday and Friday, Milo's teacher was out sick and there are no substitutes. He and his classmates spent the day doodling at the back of other classrooms, in small groups of 3.

What with the strikes and Milo's teacher being absent without a substitute, he's averaged exactly three days of school a week. That's only one day less than the normal French four-day week, but from us who are used to five full days of school a week, it's nothing short of shocking. We hope the situation gets better soon.

The Toussaint vacation officially started after school on Friday. We are getting ready for 10 days of vacation. You'll find out where next post!

children.title: Basile
children.description: We took advantage of a strike day to invite Felix's school buddy Basile to spend the day at our house. We taught him about pumpkin carving.

children.title: Basile 2
children.description:
Basile took to the carving but strayed away from the classic Jack O Lantern. His pumpkin had 3 letters carved in it: B for Basile, F for Felix and M for Milo.

Each boy points to his letter.

children.title: Coloring
children.description:
Milo doesn't usually particularly care for coloring, but he has been fervently working his way through a thick "Halloween Coloring Book" which Nana gave him.

We think his devotion to this book comes from missing all things American in general and Halloween in particular.

children.title: Costumes
children.description: Another hint of Halloween in the air: playing dress-up with the cousins.

children.title: Street Art
children.description: Inspired by a documentary we watched recently, we took on to explore the street artists of Paris.

children.title: Graffiti
children.description: Really, in most cases, "street art" just means "graffiti".

children.title: Belleville
children.description:
Belleville, a neighborhood near our house, is a favorite stomping ground of street artists.

We wandered the streets of Belleville in search of their marks.

children.title: Rue Dénoyez
children.description:
Rue Dénoyez. A loose organization of artists called Fichez Nous la Paix work together to schedule their creations.

There's so much art going on on this street, often when people come home from work the color scheme of their street has changed from when they left.

children.title: Monster Bunny
children.description: The whole street is covered in graffiti. No square foot is spared.

children.title: Planter
children.description: Can you see the ceramic-decorated planter? They are everywhere on Rue Dénoyez. Perhaps the street artists made some sort of deal with the Belleville city hall: we get to paint freely on every surface, in exchange we create cool planters and maintain plants in them.

children.title: Monster
children.description: Don't Mess with Lucie

children.title: Space Invader
children.description:
This playful little ceramic is by "Space Invader", a fairly famous street artist who has been plastering his creations all over Paris and Los Angeles for years.

Now that we're looking out for them, we notice them all around town in the strangest places.

children.title: La Villette
children.description:
La Villette, a science museum.

The giant mirror ball is La Géode, an IMAX theatre.

children.title: Geode
children.description: Who loves not having school on Wednesday? We do! We do!

children.title: 3D
children.description: Inside la Géode, we saw a 3D movie about giant prehistoric sea monsters.

children.title: Cité des Enfants
children.description: La Villette is a science museum which includes "la Cité des Enfants", a very fun discovery museum (with a branch targeted at 2 to 7 year-olds and another one for 5 to 12 year-olds).

children.title: Magic Carpet
children.description: One section of la Cité des Enfants is devoted to uncovering the mysteries of TV studios and movie sets.

children.title: Météo
children.description: Felix predicted rain for the weekend. I guess HE is the one to blame for the crappy weather we've been getting.

children.title: Song
children.description: Milo kept holding his guitar at the most improbable angles.

children.title: Driving
children.description: Are we there yet?

children.title: Wheel
children.description: La Villette is a huge complex. There is much more to see than just the discovery museum. We really liked le Jardin des Vents et des Dunes. It has all sort of unusual play structures: trampolines, tunnels, ropes and this turning wheel.

children.title: Place de la Concorde
children.description:
Solo expedition for Felix and Dean while Lucie stayed home with a sick Milo.

The father-son team opted for a manly trip to the army museum at Les Invalides.

children.title: Cannons
children.description:
Felix is deeply pacifist but fascinated by army stuff.

He'd be very happy to design an aircraft carrier for the navy as long as they promise not to use it.

children.title: Strike
children.description:
The strikes continue. The target: a proposed new law reforming the pension system. It would raise the early retirement age from 60 to 62 and the age of full pension entitlement from 65 to 67, starting in 2018 and 2016 respectively.

On Thursday, at least 312 high schools were hit by protests. A lot of them participated at the march below, which started at Jussieu university in Paris. Dean went to check it out.

Reports varied as to how many demonstrators were at this particular march. The police said 4000, the unions said 17,000.

children.title: Manif
children.description:
Shh! Don't tell the students that France's pension system is unsustainable:
  • In 1960, there were 4.69 active workers per retiree.
  • In 1990, there were 2.10 active workers per retiree.
  • In 2010, there are only 1.5 active workers per retiree.

The system will be bankrupt long before these kids retire.

They *should* be striking, but to push the pension age up to 70, not to keep it down. But maybe their teachers haven't been too keen to tell them about the demographic burden.

children.title: Protest Food
children.description:
The revolution will be catered.

Unlike the food vendors at the protests, at least a quarter of French gas stations have run dry. All 11 of France’s active refineries have been on strike for at least a week, and the main gas shipping port at Marseille is also on strike.

Thank goodness we drive very rarely. So far, the metro (or at least the parts we ride on) has been surprisingly unaffected.

children.title: Carla
children.description:
The sign reads "Carla: one est comme toi. On s'fait basier par NICOLAS."

"Carla (Bruni), we're like you: we've been fucked by Nicolas (Sarkozy)."

Carla Bruni is a popular singer who married Nicolas Sarkozy soon after he became president.
